posts.text:
After 3 years with AI, 100s of LinkedIn posts, and 70+ Kleo user calls‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve finally cracked my workflow.

Most people open ChatGPT and type:

‚ÄúWrite me a LinkedIn post on [topic].‚Äù

That‚Äôs why the output feels generic and nothing like you.

The problem isn‚Äôt AI.
The problem is your workflow.

Here's what my workflow looks like:

1. Inputs

AI needs context to write in your style, about your topics, with your knowledge.

- Past posts to match your style
- Info on who you are and what you do
- Call transcripts, SOPs, blog posts... for knowledge
- Proven post templates for winning formats
- Idea swipes from Reddit, X, LinkedIn, blogs...

2. Chat

AI rarely one-shots posts ready to publish. Instead, you chat with it and use your inputs to "build" the post.

Think of it like Cursor for LinkedIn posts:

You don‚Äôt expect Cursor to write perfect code in one go.

You iterate with it; ask for snippets, refactors, or alternative approaches. Each step compounds until you‚Äôve got clean, working code.

Do the same with post writing:

- "What's trending on Reddit, X, LinkedIn..."
- "Give me post ideas from my knowledge base"
- "Give me a template for [topic]"
- "Write me 5 hook variations"
- "Write my post using this hook"
- "Rewrite this part"

3. Publish

By now 90% of the post is done, the rest is polish.

- Preview how it'll look on LinkedIn
- Tweak the formatting for content UX
- Add your visual
- Schedule and post

Your expertise goes in.
AI organises and sharpens it.
The output feels 100% yours (only faster).

This is the exact workflow we‚Äôve built into Kleo 2.0.

I‚Äôve also streamlined the entire process. Get it here for FREE: https://lnkd.in/eNjSWvjQ

In 2022, I had 0 followers and no idea how to write.

I was never a fan of social media, but knew LinkedIn could change my business forever (and it did).

So I went down the rabbit hole:

1. Spent $1,000s on courses and coaching 
2. Consumed (often conflicting) advice
3. Tried every writing tool out there

I met Lara along the way, and we started working towards our first 10,000 followers.

But what actually worked?

- Scrolling through socials
- Reading industry news
- Staying on top of industry trends
- Screenshotting posts for ideas
- Saving content for "knowledge"

Not just on LinkedIn, but Twitter, Reddit, and blogs too.

That became my swipe file: inspiration for topics, hooks, formats, angles, the content...

This was the biggest unlock that helped me hit 100M+ impressions and grow to 200K followers.

But I've realised:

The problem wasn't finding inspiration, it was turning inspiration into execution.

And this is where every writing tool has failed me.

- Generic templates
- Simply recycling my old content
- Limited databases with basic outputs

None of them could take my ideas and turn them into expert-led content that sounds like me.

So I rebuilt Kleo with Lara to solve our own problem.

The first version worked. You could see viral content instantly, but copying others isn‚Äôt a worthwhile strategy.

Building your own voice that can scale itself is.

I‚Äôm building Kleo to take ANY inspiration:

And turn it into posts that feel like you.

If you‚Äôre struggling to stay consistent, you‚Äôre not facing a creativity problem.

Kleo 2.0 is that system.

posts.text:
Google's leaked documents confirmed it.

They use a secret metric called siteAuthority to determine who to trust.

The sites dominating search in 2025 and beyond aren't chasing keywords. They're owning entire topics.

7-step framework for building topical authority:

1. Define your core topic domain

Pick a niche you can actually dominate. "Email marketing" is too broad. "Email marketing for SaaS companies" works. Most people fail here by going too wide.

2. Uncover your entire topic universe

Map every subtopic and user question. Use Reddit, Quora, People Also Ask, competitor analysis. You need 1,000s of keywords, not 20.

3. Group keywords into content clusters

Use SERP-based clustering. If two keywords show 70%+ overlap in top-ranking URLs, they belong on the same page. Pattern-based tools miss this completely.

Tool tip: I cluster keywords with Keyword Insights.

4. Architect topic hubs

Create pillar pages for broad topics. Build cluster pages for specific subtopics. Internally link them both ways. This signals comprehensive coverage to Google.

5. Execute content gap analysis

Find every cluster where competitors rank, but you don't. Prioritize by search volume and difficulty. These are your highest-ROI opportunities.

6. Create content with information gain

Add unique value. Original research, firsthand experience, expert analysis. AI 'consensus' content doesn't tend to build authority.

7. Weave strategic internal links

Hub-and-spoke model. Every cluster links to its pillar. Every pillar links to all clusters. No page should be orphaned (left on its own).

Sites that master this see 57% faster traffic growth than those that don't (Graphite, 2024).

The question isn't whether to build topical authority.

It's whether you'll build it before your competitors do.

posts.text:
I just went on Greg Isenberg's podcast and broke down 6 proven playbooks that took bootstrapped SaaS from $0 to $300K MRR.

Real examples.
Real numbers.
Real tactics you can copy.

Here's how to get customers for your SaaS in 2026:

(PS. Watch the podcast here: https://lnkd.in/e-CjhaAz)

The companies we're reverse engineering:

- Kleo: $61K MRR
- TrustMRR: $24K MRR (in 30 days)
- Teachizy: $65K MRR
- Tally: $338K MRR
- LocalRank: $47K MRR
- Mailscale: $100K+ MRR

Playbook 1: The Waitlist Strategy

We used this for Kleo. Hit $61K MRR in 53 days.

The framework: Content ‚Üí Email ‚Üí Webinar

Create "edusales" content that subtly teases your product. Don't hard sell. Lead with value. Plug your tool in ONE bullet point.

Launch beta to your waitlist with early-bird lifetime discount.

We offered the first 500 users lifetime access for $59 (normally $99).

This creates scarcity and FOMO.

Hit $61K MRR before even launching publicly.

Stack your calendar with customer calls. Use first 500 users to iterate. Then relaunch to second cohort at a higher price.

Playbook 2: The Wave Surfer Strategy

TrustMR by Marc Lou: $24K MRR in 30 days.

Pieter Levels tweeted, complaining about fake MRR screenshots on X.

Marc shipped TrustMRR within 48 hours.

He didn't use his own audience. He piggybacked on Pieter‚Äôs virality.

Ship fast. Quit fast if it doesn't work.

Build virality into the product. TrustMRR is inherently shareable.

When you get massive attention but low intent, sell ads instead of subscriptions.

Playbook 3: Language Arbitrage Strategy

Teachizy: $65K MRR

They took Kajabi/Teachable and made it 100% French.

That's it. Same product. Different language.

SEO in other languages = marketing on easy mode. High volume. Low competition. It's what SEO in English looked like in the early 2000s.

Playbook 4: AI Search Strategy

Tally: $338K MRR

They became the #1 recommended form builder in ChatGPT.

Result: 2,000+ new users from AI search in 2025 alone.

Created comprehensive alternatives pages and "best of" articles. When people search "Typeform alternative" in ChatGPT, Tally shows up first.

Traffic from ChatGPT converts 4-5x better than Google. In some cases, 17x better.

Why? People trust ChatGPT like a friend.

Plus ChatGPT gives 2-3 recommendations vs 1,000 blue links.

The next 6 months are the biggest window to take advantage of this.

Playbook 5: Signal Search Strategy

LocalRank: $47K MRR. Made $5K MRR on day one.

They shipped ONE feature (a heat map) to test market response.

This let them validate demand before investing months into a full platform.

They launched it on YouTube and X (YouTube drove 80% of signups)

Oops, I've run out of characters.

Check out Playbook 6: High Ticket Ad Strategy (Mailscale: $100K MRR) in the comments üëá

I spent 8 hours researching these SaaS strategies so you don't have to...

Which playbook do you like best?

posts.text:
This strategy got us to $62K MRR in 53 days:

Yesterday, my co-founder Rob gave away our entire launch playbook on Greg Isenberg's podcast.

(plus 5 other playbooks, watch the full podcast here: https://lnkd.in/eKEJrwbX)

Here's our Kleo launch playbook breakdown:

Step 1: Content that doesn't feel like selling

I call this 'edu-sales.'

We created posts that led with value first.

Then we included the Kleo waitlist signup link in the posts only when it logically supported the education.

Most founders scream about their product at the top of every post. We did the opposite.

We taught people how to write better LinkedIn content. Then casually mentioned how Kleo could help.

Step 2: Launch to your waitlist with scarcity

We built a 20,000+ person waitlist before launch.

Then we opened beta access to just 500 people at $59/mo lifetime access (normal price: $99/mo).

The constraint was real. We needed beta testers to bash bugs and validate features.

But it also created urgency because the spots were genuinely limited, the lifetime discount was real, and people moved fast.

Step 3: Run webinars for fence-sitters

A lot of our sales came from the email launch alone.

But some people needed more convincing.

So we ran a couple 1-hour webinars to convert the fence-sitters.

This wasn't for everyone. Just for the people on the waitlist who hadn't pulled the trigger yet.

The webinars gave us that final push to convert more people.

Step 4: Talk to 50+ customers

Me and my co-founders stacked our calendars with customer calls.

We learned which features people loved, where the bugs were, and what to ship next.

This wasn't optional. It was the point of this strategy.

Step 5: Repeat with a second cohort

Second beta launch at $79/mo lifetime access.

We followed the same process, made more improvements, and shipped an even better product.

Now we're preparing for our public launch at $99/mo.

We used this exact playbook twice:

- Once for Kleo ($62K in 53 days)
- Once for Mentions ($20K in 30 days)

It works.

Your brand could be mentioned 10,000 times in ChatGPT responses.

Your product could be recommended in Claude conversations.

None of that shows up in your traffic data.

That's why I've been building Mentions for the past few months. I needed a way to track this visibility.

Because the future of SEO isn't just ranking on Google.

It's being visible wherever people ask questions.

posts.text:
Planning new SEO content for 2026?

PLEASE do this first:

1. Get all your blog URLs into a spreadsheet.

Use Screaming Frog to crawl and export. It provides other useful information like titles and descriptions.

Connect further data sources:

- Ahrefs
- Google Analytics
- Google Search Console

2. Enter each URL into Google Search Console or Ahrefs and find its best-ranking keywords.

Add this data to the spreadsheet for each page:

- Primary keyword (your main keyword)
- Secondary keywords (variations and similar)
- Current position for your target keyword(s)

If a URL isn't ranking for anything?

Find the most relevant keywords using Ahrefs.

Then...

3. Audit each blog post and assign actions:

- Leave: Content that‚Äôs reached its full potential
- Merge: Cannibalising or extremely similar content
- Delete: Content that no longer offers value to users
- Update: Small changes to improve the performance
- Rewrite: Large changes to improve the performance

4. Spend a few weeks in Q1 implementing these actions to get more out of your existing assets.

Prioritise updates and rewrites that have:

- Target keywords in positions 4-20
- Higher conversion and $ potential
- Easy improvement opportunities

Remember:

Not all of your Q1 content needs to be new. Look at your existing content first.

You're likely sitting on many quick wins.

posts.text:
I've been saying this for 17 months. The data keeps proving the same thing.

Ahrefs released a study analysing 600,000 pages.

The data shows Google doesn't penalise AI content. The correlation between AI usage and rankings was 0.011. Basically zero.

This might sound familiar.

Back in April 2024, we ran a similar analysis at Byword across 5,000 sites right after Google's update that "targeted AI content."

Same result. AI content wasn't the problem.

But here's what everyone missed then (and what most are still missing now):

The sites that got hit weren't using AI wrong. They were doing content wrong.

Our data showed sites covering random topics saw a -26.4% traffic drop. While focused sites using AI actually grew 6.2%.

It was never about the tool. It was about the strategy.

The Ahrefs study confirms it again. They found 81.9% of top-ranking pages use a mix of AI and human content.

Pure AI content rarely hits position one, but neither does pure human content dominate.

The pattern is clear: Google cares about quality and relevance. Not your writing process.

If you've been avoiding AI because you're scared of penalties, you've been optimising for the wrong thing.

As Ahrefs put it: "Google probably doesn't care how you made the content. It simply cares whether searchers find it helpful."

Focus your content. Serve your niche. Use whatever tools help you do that better.

The data's been showing this for 2 years.

posts.text:
How does AI search actually work today?

This is what happens between ask and answer:

Unlike older models that leaned on recall, GPT-5 grounds answers in live sources with a search-and-verify loop.

1. Your Question

Uses chat history and general location for relevance.

2. Decide to Search

If the model needs fresh, verifiable, or comparative info, it turns on search.

3. Plan Search

Breaks your ask into sub-queries, chooses a provider, sets recency or domain limits.

4A. Web Retrieval

Hits a search index with keywords and vectors, re-ranks for relevance, freshness, and diversity, and returns candidate URLs/snippets.

4B‚ÄìF. Where that index comes from

- Websites: Public pages and feeds
- Collect Pages: Crawlers/APIs fetch, follow robots.txt
- Clean & Split: Strip boilerplate; chunk with metadata
- Index for Search: Make embeddings; add entities/links
- Search Index: Searchable store for keyword and vector

5. Open Pages

Fetches the chosen URLs, renders HTML, follows redirects, normalizes canonicals.

6. Evidence

Pulls clean, cited snippets with dates and URLs; filters out duplicates.

7. Write Answer

Composes from the evidence; can add steps, tables, comparisons, citations.

8. Quality Check

Groundedness and policy screens; flags conflicting claims across sources.

9. Answer

Final explanation with sources and follow-ups. Clicks and re-asks feed a small feedback loop for better routing next time.

Curious to know how you show up in AI answers?

Use Mentions.

posts.text:
This is the CEO of Google reacting to my SEO Heist.

Sundar Pichai in an interview with The Verge, talking about something I published.

I'm sitting at my desk, watching the interview, and there it is. The CEO of a $3 trillion company discussing my experiment.

Here's what happened:

Nearly 2 years ago, I executed what became known as the "SEO Heist."

I exported a competitor's entire sitemap. Then I used AI to create 1,800 articles at scale, targeting the exact same keywords.

The result?

489,509 visitors in that month alone. 3.6 million in total traffic 'stolen' from that competitor.

The post went viral. 20M+ views across all platforms. Huge publications covered it. SEO Twitter exploded.

But I never expected this.

The thing about doing public experiments is you never know where they'll land. You put something out there, and it takes on a life of its own.

Suddenly you're not just a guy testing SEO tactics with AI-generated content. You're a case study in a conversation about search quality.

I'm not celebrating or gloating. I'm just thinking about how weird the internet is.

One day you're a person with a laptop, a pretty crazy idea, and an AI tool that we built.

And a few weeks later, the CEO of Google is discussing your post in an interview.

That's the world we live in now.

posts.text:
Reddit just lost 82% of its AI citations overnight.

(and Wall Street noticed)

ChatGPT's Reddit citations dropped from 29.2% to 5.3% in days. And their stock fell 15% over 8 days.

The cause? Google changed a single indexing parameter that limited what LLMs could access in search results.

One technical tweak. Billions in market value gone.

Here's what nobody's talking about:

Reddit didn't change anything. Their content is still there. Their users are still posting. Their traffic didn't collapse.

But their value to AI companies evaporated.

This reveals something critical about the new internet economy.

We're not just building on platforms anymore. We're building on whether AI models can see those platforms.

Reddit's entire AI strategy was based on being visible to LLMs. They signed a $60M deal with Google for AI training data.

Then Google's indexing change made Reddit less accessible to ChatGPT specifically.

The market reacted like Reddit lost a major revenue stream. Because in a way, they did.

The dependency goes both ways now:

Companies depend on AI visibility the same way they used to depend on SEO.

AI companies depend on access to fresh, human-generated content.

When that connection breaks, billions disappear.

Here's the irony: Reddit signed that $60M data-sharing deal with Google over a year ago. They're now in talks for deeper AI integration to funnel Google traffic into Reddit forums for content generation.

They're negotiating with the same company whose parameter change caused the damage...

Did we just watch the first major AI visibility crisis play out in real time?

posts.text:
I‚Äôm seeing tons of misleading SEO advice for AI search.

Let‚Äôs bust 5 of the biggest myths:

1. ‚ÄúYou need to write in a special way for LLMs to understand you‚Äù

LLMs are trained on billions of examples of natural language: conversations, books, web pages, social media. They learn patterns, context, and slang the way people actually write.

That makes them robust to typos, casual grammar, and everyday phrasing. In other words: they‚Äôre built to process normal human language, not rigid SEO-style writing.

2. ‚ÄúAdding an llms.txt file will improve visibility in AI search results‚Äù

llms.txt is not a ranking factor. It‚Äôs a proposed standard for telling AI models what they can or can‚Äôt use, but most don‚Äôt even honor it.

Publishing one doesn‚Äôt boost how often you show up in AI answers, visibility comes from shaping your brand narrative across sites, communities, and trusted sources, not from a text file.

3. ‚ÄúAI will reliably use schema markup to generate answers‚Äù

Schema is intended as a hint, not a guarantee. Most LLMs don‚Äôt consistently parse schema, often ignore it when conflicting content exists, or give higher weight to context from non-schema sources.

Presence of schema does not assure inclusion in generated answers.

4. ‚ÄúLLMs just pulls from the first page of Google results‚Äù

AI answers don‚Äôt simply mirror the SERP. Yes, there‚Äôs overlap with the top 10 results, but it varies a lot:

- Perplexity: 82% overlap
- Google AI Mode: 35% overlap
- ChatGPT: 28% overlap

And beyond SERPs, 40% of AI answers come from Reddit and other community-driven sources. Meaning: ranking on page one isn‚Äôt enough, visibility in AI requires presence across forums, news, and niche sites too.

5. ‚ÄúYou need special tactics to win spots in AI Overviews‚Äù

Google has been clear that there isn‚Äôt a hidden trick. AI Overviews rely on the same fundamentals as organic search: high-quality, relevant, authoritative content.

If your pages already perform well in traditional search, they‚Äôre eligible to be surfaced in AI Overviews. What matters is clarity, expertise, and trustworthiness, not special tactics or gimmicks.

Did I miss any big myths you‚Äôve seen?

After 3 years with AI, 100s of LinkedIn posts, and 50+ Kleo user calls‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve finally cracked my workflow.

Most people open ChatGPT and type:

‚ÄúWrite me a LinkedIn post on [topic].‚Äù

That‚Äôs why the output feels generic and nothing like you.

The problem isn‚Äôt AI. 
The problem is your workflow.

Here's what my workflow looks like:

1. Inputs

AI needs context to write in your style, about your topics, with your knowledge.

- Past posts to match your style
- Info on who you are and what you do
- Call transcripts, SOPs, blog posts... for knowledge
- Proven post templates for winning formats
- Idea swipes from Reddit, X, LinkedIn, blogs...

2. Chat

AI rarely one-shots posts ready to publish. Instead, you chat with it and use your inputs to "build" the post.

Think of it like Cursor for LinkedIn posts:

You don‚Äôt expect Cursor to write perfect code in one go. 

You iterate with it; ask for snippets, refactors, or alternative approaches. Each step compounds until you‚Äôve got clean, working code.

Do the same with post writing:

- "What's trending on Reddit, X, LinkedIn..."
- "Give me post ideas from my knowledge base"
- "Give me a template for [topic]"
- "Write me 5 hook variations"
- "Write my post using this hook"
- "Re-write this part"

3. Publish

By now 90% of the post is done, the rest is polish.

- Preview how it'll look on LinkedIn
- Tweak the formatting for content UX
- Add your visual
- Schedule and post

Your expertise goes in.
AI organises and sharpens it.
The output feels 100% yours (only faster).

This is the exact workflow I‚Äôve built into Kleo 2.0.

How I rank businesses inside LLMs:

AI platforms handle millions of daily queries, Google now shows AI summaries on 1 in 5 searches, Google is making AI Mode the default.

This isn't just another SEO hype.

But successful AI SEO follows 7 key steps that most people completely miss.

Here's my AI SEO playbook:

Step 1: Map your customer questions

Write down every question from your sales calls. Those same questions are being asked in ChatGPT right now.

But don't stop there. Map the follow-up questions too. LLMs love comprehensive answers.

Step 2: Create answer-focused pages

Build pages that directly answer those questions. Skip the fluff and get straight to solutions.

Step 3: Get authentic forum mentions

Make a real account on forums like Reddit. Use your real name and company. Give genuinely helpful answers in relevant threads.

Answer long-tail questions others ignore. These feed directly into LLM responses.

But don't spam. Communities spot fake accounts instantly.

Step 4: Publish YouTube videos

Target specific problems your customers face. LLMs love video citations for complex topics.

Focus on topics where written content falls short.

Step 5: Build strategic affiliate partnerships

Partner with creators who naturally mention your solutions. Authentic recommendations carry more weight than ads.

Step 6: Maximise quality citations everywhere

Get mentioned in blog posts, forums, podcasts. More citations equal more LLM visibility.

Quality beats quantity. One mention in a trusted source outperforms ten low-quality ones.

Step 7: Track your brand mentions religiously

Use a tool like Mentions to monitor when and how your brand (and each competitor) appears.

The AI revolution isn't killing SEO. It's creating new opportunities for companies willing to adapt.

The biggest opportunity?

Even early-stage companies can win immediately.

You don't need domain authority like Google. You just need to get cited and you‚Äôll start showing up.

posts.text:
How does AI search actually work today?

This is what happens between ask and answer:

Unlike older models that leaned on recall, GPT-5 grounds answers in live sources with a search-and-verify loop.

1. Your Question

Uses chat history and general location for relevance.

2. Decide to Search

If the model needs fresh, verifiable, or comparative info, it turns on search.

3. Plan Search

Breaks your ask into sub-queries, chooses a provider, sets recency or domain limits.

4A. Web Retrieval

Hits a search index with keywords and vectors, re-ranks for relevance, freshness, and diversity, and returns candidate URLs/snippets.

4B‚ÄìF. Where that index comes from

- Websites: Public pages and feeds
- Collect Pages: Crawlers/APIs fetch, follow robots.txt
- Clean & Split: Strip boilerplate; chunk with metadata
- Index for Search: Make embeddings; add entities/links
- Search Index: Searchable store for keyword and vector

5. Open Pages

Fetches the chosen URLs, renders HTML, follows redirects, normalizes canonicals.

6. Evidence

Pulls clean, cited snippets with dates and URLs; filters out duplicates.

7. Write Answer

Composes from the evidence; can add steps, tables, comparisons, citations.

8. Quality Check

Groundedness and policy screens; flags conflicting claims across sources.

9. Answer

Final explanation with sources and follow-ups. Clicks and re-asks feed a small feedback loop for better routing next time.

Curious to know how you show up in AI answers?

Use Mentions.

posts.text:
I‚Äôm seeing tons of misleading SEO advice for AI search.

Let‚Äôs bust 5 of the biggest myths:

1. ‚ÄúYou need to write in a special way for LLMs to understand you‚Äù

LLMs are trained on billions of examples of natural language: conversations, books, web pages, social media. They learn patterns, context, and slang the way people actually write.

That makes them robust to typos, casual grammar, and everyday phrasing. In other words: they‚Äôre built to process normal human language, not rigid SEO-style writing.

2. ‚ÄúAdding an llms.txt file will improve visibility in AI search results‚Äù

llms.txt is not a ranking factor. It‚Äôs a proposed standard for telling AI models what they can or can‚Äôt use, but most don‚Äôt even honor it.

Publishing one doesn‚Äôt boost how often you show up in AI answers, visibility comes from shaping your brand narrative across sites, communities, and trusted sources, not from a text file.

3. ‚ÄúAI will reliably use schema markup to generate answers‚Äù

Schema is intended as a hint, not a guarantee. Most LLMs don‚Äôt consistently parse schema, often ignore it when conflicting content exists, or give higher weight to context from non-schema sources.

Presence of schema does not assure inclusion in generated answers.

4. ‚ÄúLLMs just pulls from the first page of Google results‚Äù

AI answers don‚Äôt simply mirror the SERP. Yes, there‚Äôs overlap with the top 10 results, but it varies a lot:

- Perplexity: 82% overlap
- Google AI Mode: 35% overlap
- ChatGPT: 28% overlap

And beyond SERPs, 40% of AI answers come from Reddit and other community-driven sources. Meaning: ranking on page one isn‚Äôt enough, visibility in AI requires presence across forums, news, and niche sites too.

5. ‚ÄúYou need special tactics to win spots in AI Overviews‚Äù

Google has been clear that there isn‚Äôt a hidden trick. AI Overviews rely on the same fundamentals as organic search: high-quality, relevant, authoritative content.

If your pages already perform well in traditional search, they‚Äôre eligible to be surfaced in AI Overviews. What matters is clarity, expertise, and trustworthiness, not special tactics or gimmicks.

Did I miss any big myths you‚Äôve seen?

posts.text:
OpenAI just leaked how people use ChatGPT:

- Practical Guidance: 28.3%
- Writing: 28.1%
- Seeking Information: 21.3%
- Technical Help: 7.5%
- Multimedia: 6.0%
- Other / Unknown: 4.6%
- Self-Expression: 4.3%

Nearly 80% of usage = Practical Guidance, Writing, and Seeking Information.

The rest (Tech Help, Multimedia, Self-Expression) are niche but still significant, especially where ChatGPT has unique capabilities (coding, image generation, companionship).

ChatGPT processes 2.5B queries a day, and nearly 50% (~1.24B daily, ~37B monthly) happen where brands can be mentioned, like Seeking Information or Practical Guidance.

Tools like Mentions.so help you track exactly when and how you‚Äôre appearing for important queries.

Here's a breakdown of each:

1. Practical Guidance (28.3%)

Practical Guidance has been stable YoY at ~29% of all usage. It‚Äôs the most common use case overall, and especially important outside of work.

Education is huge: ~10% of all ChatGPT conversations are tutoring/teaching.

Breakdown: Tutoring/teaching (10.2%), how-to advice (8.5%), health/fitness/self-care (5.7%), creative ideation (3.9%).

2. Writing (28.1%)

Writing has declined in share YoY (down from 36%) but is still the dominant work-related category (40% of all work messages).

Two-thirds are about editing/modifying user text, not generating fresh content.

Breakdown: Edit/critique provided text (10.6%), personal writing/communication (8.0%), translation (4.5%), argument/summary generation (3.6%), fiction (1.4%).

3. Seeking Information (21.3%)

This is the fastest-growing category YoY (up from 14%).

Functions almost like web search, but with more conversational, tailored answers (e.g. fact lookups, news, product comparisons).

Breakdown: Specific info (18.3%), purchasable products (2.1%), recipes (0.9%).

4. Technical Help (7.5%)

Share has fallen YoY (down from 12%), partly because coding queries are moving to APIs and code-specific tools.

Breakdown: Programming (4.2%), math (3.0%), data analysis (0.4%).

5. Multimedia (6.0%)

Saw a huge spike in April 2025 when image generation was launched, then stabilized at a higher baseline.

Breakdown: Create image (4.2%), analyze image (0.6%), other media (1.1%).

6. Other / Unknown (4.6%)

Captures edge cases and ambiguous intent.

Represents a background share of noise and meta-queries (users asking about ChatGPT itself).

Breakdown: Asking about the model (0.4%), other/unclear (4.1%).

7. Self-Expression (4.3%)

Very small share, despite media narratives about ‚ÄúAI companionship.‚Äù

Other studies (like Zao-Sanders 2025) estimated companionship was the #1 AI use case, but ChatGPT‚Äôs own logs show otherwise.

Breakdown: Greetings/chitchat (2.0%), relationships/personal reflection (1.9%), games/role play (0.4%).

Which use case do you use ChatGPT for the most?

posts.text:
The vase story is the best marketing lesson I know.

A ceramics teacher split their class in two:

Group A was graded on quantity. Make as many vases as possible.

Group B was graded on quality. Make just one perfect vase.

At the end of the term, the best vases came from the quantity group.

Why?

Because while one group was sketching the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù vase, the other group was making, failing, learning, improving.

That‚Äôs exactly how marketing works.

You don‚Äôt find the perfect campaign in a deck.

You find it in the field.

Quantity-first marketers launch campaigns, test angles, push content, run ads, gather data.

Every experiment is a ‚Äúvase‚Äù. They learn fast, double down on what works, cut what doesn‚Äôt.

Quality-first marketers try to build the perfect campaign before launch. Endless brainstorms, revisions, and decks.

By the time it‚Äôs live, the market has already shifted, and they‚Äôve learned nothing in the process.

The best marketers aren‚Äôt the ones with the prettiest presentations.

They‚Äôre the ones running more experiments than everyone else.

Quantity breeds quality.

Here‚Äôs how:

1. GPT-5 isn‚Äôt built to memorize the world‚Äôs knowledge.

OpenAI deliberately designed it to be a reasoning engine, a brain on top of tools. Instead of hoarding facts, it retrieves them in real time.

2. Grounding is everything.

Nick Turley from OpenAI put it best:

‚ÄúThe right product is LLMs connected to ground truth, and that‚Äôs why we brought search to ChatGPT and I think that makes a huge difference.‚Äù

Without grounding, GPT-5 is virtually useless.

3. That is where SEO comes in.

If your content isn‚Äôt discoverable, optimized, and credible, GPT-5 (along with every other LLM) can‚Äôt use it.

SEO is the oxygen. GPT-5 is the brain.

The brain (reasoning engine) can think, but without oxygen (SEO content), it can‚Äôt survive.

Grounding is the lungs, pulling in air (information) in real time.

But the quality of that air depends on SEO.

GPT-5 has made SEO the foundation of AI search.

10 prompts to turn 5 hours of SEO into 5 minutes:

1. SEO Audit

Act as an expert SEO consultant. Audit the website {DOMAIN}. Identify key issues across technical SEO, content gaps, on-page optimisation, backlinks, and UX. Then prioritise top fixes and opportunities.

2. TASM (Total Addressable Search Market)

Help me define the Total Addressable Search Market for {PRODUCT/SERVICE/DOMAIN}. Group keywords into TOFU/MOFU/BOFU clusters. Include intent, content types, and estimated opportunity.

3. Search Intent Reverse Engineering

For the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}‚Äô, analyse search intent. Break it into primary and secondary user goals. Suggest ideal content format, page structure, and CTA strategy.

4. Programmatic SEO Template Generator

Create a reusable SEO article template for ‚Äò{KEYWORD FRAMEWORK}‚Äô, designed for programmatic generation. Include intro, modular blocks (tables, FAQs, lists), and recommended internal/external links.

5. Entity-Optimised Article Creator

Write a long-form article for the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}'. Optimise for AI Overviews and semantic SEO. Include entities, subtopics, FAQs, and a concise summary answer at the top.

6. Topical Authority Builder

Build a topical map for the niche ‚Äò{NICHE}‚Äô. Show the main pillar pages, cluster topics, and long-tail supporting articles needed to build topical authority.

7. SERP Competitor Teardown

posts.text:
Before: 300+ blog posts, 1K/mo (declining) traffic.

After: 0 new blog posts, 120K/mo traffic.

How? Content optimisation.

Here's the background:

The client had published 300+ posts over 2 years but only hit ~1K/mo traffic (and it was falling). They‚Äôd invested 6-figures and wanted more out of what they already had.

Here's what we did:

1. Content audit

We analysed all 300+ posts and identified:

- Nearly-ranking posts (low-hanging fruit)
- Overlapping posts that could be merged
- Posts with potential but poorly optimised
- Content offering little/no value to users or Google
- Posts targeting multiple intents that should be split

We prioritised what could move the needle fastest.

2. Content optimisation

We optimised content with the most potential (~20%).

For each, we improved:

- Introduction
- Internal linking
- SERP snippets
- Topic coverage
- Matching intent
- Term frequency
- Content structure

We completed this over a 90-day sprint.

And hit 120K+/mo in 180 days.

Publishing more isn‚Äôt always the answer.

Optimising what you already have can drive bigger wins.

Traditional SEO was about backlinks.

LLM SEO is about mentions.

As search shifts from "10 blue links" to AI-generated answers, it‚Äôs about being part of the answer training set.

LLM SEO consists of 2 core strategies:

1. Earned = Mentions

LLMs like ChatGPT don‚Äôt pull answers out of thin air.

They generate responses by:

- Running a query
- Retrieving relevant URLs
- Summarising from those pages

If your brand is consistently mentioned across those sources, you‚Äôre more likely to be included in the answer (even if your site isn‚Äôt the one being shown).

It‚Äôs the new version of link building.

But instead of asking:

"How do I get more backlinks?"

You‚Äôre asking:

"How do I get mentioned in content LLMs trust?"

You win by:

1. Identifying influential source URLs
2. Getting your brand mentioned by them
3. Monitoring your mentions across AI results

Tip: Use a tool like Mentions for steps 1 and 3.

2. Owned = Content

This is your own domain.

When you optimise your site to answer specific questions clearly (using Q&A blocks, semantic HTML, topic hubs), LLMs can lift your content directly into answers.

It‚Äôs like building a mini knowledge base.

But not for people... for LLMs.

Earned and owned together help you:

- Influence what LLMs know about you
- Control how you‚Äôre represented
- Stay visible as search shifts to conversations

So the real question now is:

‚ÄúAre you part of the answer training set?‚Äù

2. Build brand equity

- Monitor online reviews and brand sentiment
- Respond to feedback and address complaints
- Build a consistent, trustworthy public image
- Use tools like Mentions.so to track visibility, sentiment, and competitors

3. Be the source

- Publish authoritative, reference-style content
- Use neutral, factual, data-backed tone
- Avoid excessive personal takes or fluff
- Regularly update key content for accuracy
- Include credible citations and external data sources

4. Embrace passage-level SEO

- Structure content into short, focused paragraphs
- Use clear subheadings for logical segmentation
- Include concise, standalone answers
- Avoid burying insights in long text block
- Add structured data (e.g. schema markup)
- Make each paragraph extractable and cite-ready

5. Cover the conversation

- Use tools like Semrush for question research
- Monitor forums/socials for emerging questions
- Identify and answer sub-questions users ask
- Add relevant FAQs and support content
- Internally link related topic clusters

6. Optimise for crawlability

- Ensure AI crawlers are allowed in robots.txt
- Verify CDN settings aren't blocking crawlers
- Submit up-to-date XML sitemaps in GSC
- Optimise for fast page speed and clean HTML
- Review server logs for GPTBot, BingBot, etc. behaviour

But first, start with an audit:

Reframe your ‚ÄúNew SEO‚Äù project as a game, and you'll become addicted to levelling up.

Level 1: Traditional SEO

- Audit your site for technical issues
- Research keywords and target quick wins
- Optimise on-page elements (titles, content)
- Build backlinks via guest posts and digital PR

Level 2: AI Search Optimisation

- Optimise content for AI Overviews
- Structure content for AI consumption
- Create citation-worthy content for AI search
- Test how your brand appears in AI search results

Level 3: Paid Search Visibility

- Launch Google Ads for high-intent keywords
- Create YouTube Search Ads targeting competitors
- Use Microsoft Ads for Bing and AI-powered search
- Track paid visibility across all search platforms

Level 4: LLM Answer SEO

- Create comprehensive, factual content for LLMs
- Build a knowledge base for AI training data
- Establish your brand as the authority LLMs reference
- Monitor brand mentions in LLMs with Mentions.so

Level 5: Brand Authority SEO

- Get unlinked brand mentions across the web
- Feature in industry roundups and expert lists
- Build brand recognition without traditional backlinks
- Track brand mention volume and sentiment

Level 6: Community SEO

- Answer questions in relevant Reddit communities
- Participate in Quora discussions in your niche
- Engage in Slack communities and Discord servers
- Build reputation in industry forums and groups

Level 7: Parasite SEO

- Repurpose content on Medium and LinkedIn Articles
- Publish Substack newsletters to rank in Google
- Guest post on high-authority platforms/websites
- Leverage existing domain authority for quick rankings

Level 8: Platform-Specific SEO

- Optimise for Amazon search if selling products
- Focus on YouTube SEO for video content
- Master TikTok's algorithm for short-form content
- Optimise App Store listings for apps/extensions

Level 9: Topic Domination

- Own conversations across ALL channels
- Create content ecosystems to reinforce each platform
- Become the go-to expert mentioned everywhere
- Monitor and maintain authority across all channels

Completed all levels?

SEO is constantly evolving in 2025.

Stay ahead or get left behind.

posts.text:
Most SEO prompts are overly complex and unhelpful.

Here are 10 that actually deliver:

1. SEO Audit

Act as an expert SEO consultant. Audit the website {DOMAIN}. Identify key issues across technical SEO, content gaps, on-page optimisation, backlinks, and UX. Then prioritise top fixes and opportunities.

2. TASM (Total Addressable Search Market)

Help me define the Total Addressable Search Market for {PRODUCT/SERVICE/DOMAIN}. Group keywords into TOFU/MOFU/BOFU clusters. Include intent, content types, and estimated opportunity.

3. Search Intent Reverse Engineering

For the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}‚Äô, analyse search intent. Break it into primary and secondary user goals. Suggest ideal content format, page structure, and CTA strategy.

4. Programmatic SEO Template Generator

Create a reusable SEO article template for ‚Äò{KEYWORD FRAMEWORK}‚Äô, designed for programmatic generation. Include intro, modular blocks (tables, FAQs, lists), and recommended internal/external links.

5. Entity-Optimised Article Creator

Write a long-form article for the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}'. Optimise for AI Overviews and semantic SEO. Include entities, subtopics, FAQs, and a concise summary answer at the top.

6. Topical Authority Builder

Build a topical map for the niche ‚Äò{NICHE}‚Äô. Show the main pillar pages, cluster topics, and long-tail supporting articles needed to build topical authority.

7. SERP Competitor Teardown

Analyse the top 10 Google results for ‚Äò{KEYWORD}'. Summarise shared features like structure, word count, format, visuals, and metadata. Then suggest how to differentiate and outperform.

8. BOFU Content Finder

Act as a B2B SEO strategist. For the product/service ‚Äò{YOUR PRODUCT OR OFFER}‚Äô, list 15 BOFU keywords that signal strong purchase intent. Include variations like ‚Äòbest‚Äô, ‚Äòvs‚Äô, ‚Äòreview‚Äô, ‚Äòalternative‚Äô, ‚Äòpricing‚Äô, ‚Äòtool‚Äô, ‚Äòagency‚Äô, and buyer pain points.

9. LLM SEO

Optimise this article {LINK} for LLM platforms like ChatGPT and Google AI Overviews. Ensure clear entity associations, direct answers, source credibility, and formatting that‚Äôs easy to extract as a summary.

10. Untapped Demand

Act as an advanced SEO and product marketing strategist. For the audience {TARGET AUDIENCE} and product {YOUR PRODUCT}, list 20 ‚Äòzero-volume‚Äô or overlooked search queries that signal deep intent or pain. These should be phrased in natural language, question-based, or problem-first. Include use cases or scenarios.

posts.text:
7 roles every great content team should cover:

1. Content/SEO Strategist

- Creates content strategy
- Audits existing content
- Optimises for search

2. Managing Editor

- Manages content production
- Ensures content is on-brand
- Reviews drafts and provides feedback

3. Writer

- Writes ebooks
- Writes blog posts
- Writes landing pages

4. Designer

- Designs illustrations
- Designs lead magnets
- Designs custom graphics

5. Outreach Specialist

- Builds backlinks to content
- Forms outbound relationships
- Pitches PR to journalists (and HARO)

6. Social Media Manager

- Executes social content strategy
- Handles engagement on social content
- Distributes other content on social media

7. Video/Audio Producer

- Creates product videos
- Creates YouTube videos
- Edits podcast audio/video

To form your content team, mix in-house and outsourcing. One person or agency can fill multiple roles.

For example:

- 1-4 outsourced to a content agency
- 5 outsourced to a digital PR agency
- 6-7 handled by 2-3 freelancers or employees

Too many companies try to get a 7-for-1 deal and wonder why they don't see incredible results.

Set your goals clearly and hire specialists accordingly.

posts.text:
If you're still in college OR hunting for your first dev job, the following should be helpful.

1. Make your resume/profile stand out: Be good on at least some front! Analyse your strengths/interests and work on them. It could be building some great product from scratch OR just your CP ratings OR anything else you like! As long as it helps you stand out and get the required visibility it wouldn't be too hard to get interview calls. 

2. Decent understanding of CI/CD pipeline and basic infra setups, You do NOT need to understand every single product being provided by every cloud provider, but having an understanding of the overall workflow and some off the shelf solutions would help you be a better engineer. 

3. CS fundamentals: In all this DSA vs Dev debate we are somehow forgetting CS fundamentals, which in my opinion are more important than learning some framework and is a more transferrable skill.

4. CGPA: Maintain a decent grade, it helps you get shortlisted for a lot of opportunities.

5. Use Social Media platforms wisely: Use platforms like LinkedIn and Twitter wisely! You could showcase your talent on these platforms and get the required visibility (rather than doomscrolling and wasting your day).

Hope posts like these are helpful, as I don't find value in posting "day in the life of an engineer" sort of content. Would appreciate if folks here could help me with topics I could write on.

posts.text:
ü§î Interview Question: What's the difference between a process and a thread?

A process is an instance of a program in execution. It has its own memory space and resources. When a program runs, it becomes a process.

A process can be broken down in more than 1 independent tasks mostly, these smaller tasks are referred as threads
Multiple threads can share the same memory space and resources of the process, allowing for parallel execution of tasks.

Processes are isolated, whereas threads within the same process can communicate directly with each other, sharing data and resources.

That‚Äôs all from my side. Thanks for your interest and time. If you read till here, a like ‚ù§Ô∏è and follow would be great üòÉ

author.occupation: Building shyftwork.com | Contractor outrank.so

posts.text:
If you are seeing this, you must be using a Operating System, so let's dive in what are the components of an OS

An OS consists of mainly two components:- 0 - User Space 1 - Kernel A User Space is the one which interacts with the user applications and provide them an interface to run

Now in the last post I shared that OS is also responsible for things like memory management, I/O devices, so where does that comes? Kernel is used for these things like interaction with an hardware, file, memory and process management.
Kernel is also referred as heart of OS

When any application needs to use hardware, or kernel space, the application/user mode uses a system call, which shifts the control to kernel and after processing the request the control shift backs to user mode

That‚Äôs all from my side. Thanks for your interest and time.
If you read till here, a like ‚ù§Ô∏è and follow would be great üòÉ

What is an Operating system and why do we even need it?

Let's say you need to take 100 rupees from the bank, so you go to the bank, there you will have to interact with the banker for getting the money, 

In here take customer as an application, banker as an OS and the money as resources like memory, CPU etc.
Operating System is an interface between our system and applications, it helps our system for resource management, isolation and security.

OS let's developer to focus on application logic instead of other things like memory management and hardware interaction.

posts.text:
How does Docker work internally? Let's dive into the mechanism that happens when you use Docker. 

Starting with the registry part: there are applications online that create an image of their system and push it out to platforms like Docker Hub. It's similar to how we put our code on GitHub.

These registries are used to grab those images. Both the Docker host and client are inside your Linux machine. Let‚Äôs say you type the command docker run mongo. What happens next?

The client (your terminal) sends a request to the Docker host (Docker Engine) to run MongoDB. If the image isn't found locally, the daemon grabs that image from Docker Hub if it‚Äôs available there.

After grabbing the image, Docker Engine will start a container running MongoDB.

You may not know the proper difference between images and containers, so here's an article -- https://lnkd.in/giHZ7pvx

How I Learned WebSockets üòéüòé

I was well-versed with HTTP servers in Node.js and Express, and I started wondering how chat applications work.

After searching on YouTube and Google, I discovered that WebSockets are used for long, bidirectional connections. With more digging, I came across Socket.IO and decided to learn it.

Socket.IO Resources I Followed:

 - @piyushgarg195 video

After this, I created a chat application: https://lnkd.in/gq6BYMAS

I also used Redis for the pub/sub model in this project, but I‚Äôll cover that in another post.

So, I thought I had learned everything about WebSockets, right? Well, not quite. A few days later, I joined 1-100xDevs by Harkirat Singh¬†and in the first lecture, I learned that Socket.IO is not necessarily the best way to use WebSockets. So, if it‚Äôs not the best, what is?

In the Week 19 lectures, I learned that we should use WebSockets directly instead of relying on Socket.IO.

After these lectures, I learned about the ws library and got to apply these concepts in a project for an intern assignment from optionolgy.¬†You can check out my project here: https://lnkd.in/gJvnNQqx

posts.text:
Mastering SQL Keys: A Deep Dive to Unlock Database Design Secrets! üöÄ #SQL #DatabaseKeys" 

0)  Primary Keys are used to identify each rows based on a unique columns, They can't have any NULL values and should always be unique. The keys which can be made as primary keys but are not are known as Alternate keys.

1)  Foreign Keys are used to establish relations between different tables, they are a unique or set of unique columns. Primary keys of the one table are established as foreign keys for another table

2)  Composite Keys are the ones which act as primary keys if one is not available in one, More than one attributes/columns act together to identify different tuples/rows

author.occupation: Building shyftwork.com | Contractor outrank.so

posts.text:
When considering SQL versus NoSQL databases, it's vital to grasp their fundamental differences:

SQL databases organize data into structured tables with rows and columns, following a relational model.
In contrast, NoSQL databases offer diverse formats such as document-based storage in MongoDB or key-value pairs in Redis.


NoSQL databases employ query languages or APIs for data retrieval and manipulation.
SQL databases, conversely, utilize SQL commands for querying and managing data.

Horizontal scaling is favored and more straightforward in NoSQL databases, allowing for seamless distribution of data across multiple servers.
Vertical scaling, on the other hand, is typically associated with SQL databases. However, achieving horizontal scaling in SQL databases can be challenging due to the stringent ACID properties.

These considerations play a crucial role in selecting the appropriate database for your project.
